events.originalText: Mariano Rivera surpassed Trevor Hoffman to become Major League Baseball's all-time career leader in saves.
events.subtitle: Mariano Rivera
events.headline: Mariano Rivera Breaks MLB Career Saves Record

events.originalText: Industrial Society and Its Future, the manifesto of American domestic terrorist Ted Kaczynski, was published in The Washington Post almost three months after it was submitted.
events.subtitle: Industrial Society and Its Future
events.headline: Ted Kaczynski Manifesto Published in The Washington Post

events.originalText: Ötzi, a well-preserved natural mummy of a man dating from about 3300 BC, was discovered by two German tourists in the Alps.
events.subtitle: Ötzi
events.headline: German Tourists Discover Ötzi Mummy in the Alps

events.originalText: An earthquake registering Mw 8.0 struck Mexico City, killing at least 9,000 people and leaving up to 100,000 homeless.
events.subtitle: 1985 Mexico City earthquake
events.headline: 8.0 Magnitude Earthquake Hits Mexico City, 9,000 Dead

events.originalText: Greek student Kostas Georgakis set himself on fire in Genoa, Italy, as a protest against the military junta of Georgios Papadopoulos.
events.subtitle: Kostas Georgakis
events.headline: Greek Student Kostas Georgakis Self-Immolation Protest in Italy

events.originalText: The first Glastonbury Festival was held at Michael Eavis's farm in Glastonbury, England.
events.subtitle: Glastonbury Festival
events.headline: First Glastonbury Festival Held at Michael Eavis's Farm

events.originalText: Korean War: A North Korean attack was repelled by Allied forces at the Battle of Nam River.
events.subtitle: Korean War
events.headline: Allied Forces Repel North Korean Attack at Battle of Nam River

events.originalText: World War II: Finland, the Soviet Union, and the United Kingdom signed the Moscow Armistice to end the Continuation War.
events.subtitle: World War II
events.headline: Moscow Armistice Signed to End Continuation War

events.originalText: World War II: Polish resistance leader Witold Pilecki allowed himself to be captured by German forces and sent to Auschwitz to gather intelligence.
events.subtitle: World War II
events.headline: Polish Resistance Leader Witold Pilecki Captured by Germans

events.originalText: New Zealand became the first country to introduce universal suffrage following the women's suffrage movement led by Kate Sheppard.
events.subtitle: Women's suffrage in New Zealand
events.headline: New Zealand Introduces Universal Suffrage Led by Kate Sheppard

events.originalText: American Civil War: The Battle of Chickamauga began in northwestern Georgia and would end in the most significant Union defeat in the Western Theater.
events.subtitle: American Civil War
events.headline: Battle of Chickamauga Begins, Significant Union Defeat

events.originalText: Near La Salette-Fallavaux in southeastern France, shepherd children Mélanie Calvat and Maximin Giraud reported a Marian apparition, now known as Our Lady of La Salette (statue pictured).
events.subtitle: La Salette-Fallavaux
events.headline: Shepherd Children Report Marian Apparition at La Salette-Fallavaux

events.originalText: American Revolutionary War: British troops engaged American forces at the first Battle of Saratoga in New York.
events.subtitle: American Revolutionary War
events.headline: British Troops Battle American Forces at Saratoga

events.originalText: Salem witch trials: Giles Corey was crushed to death for refusing to enter a plea to charges of witchcraft, reportedly asking officials for "more weight".
events.subtitle: Salem witch trials
events.headline: Giles Corey Crushed to Death in Salem Witch Trials

events.originalText: Hundred Years' War: English forces led by Edward the Black Prince decisively won the Battle of Poitiers and captured John II of France.
events.subtitle: Hundred Years' War
events.headline: Edward the Black Prince Wins Battle of Poitiers, Captures John II of France
